I'd like to get your experiences with sub withdrawal. Twice I have attempted to quit. The first time I went seven full days without any effects other than tiredness. I resumed the subs because I had to work and needed more energy. I tried again last week and went three-four days without any at all. Again, the only w/d symptoms I had were slight sniffles and tiredness. The tiredness steadily gets worse, finally becoming extreme fatigue, which is actually disabling, so I went back on low doses of sub. I'm planning to detox during a time when I have at least a week - preferably two - off work, etc., so I can get off. I've heard of vicodin-type w/ds from sub users, but I never had that. Is that something that would follow after a week of relatively milk, fatigue w/d symptoms?
have a look at the health pages   ( bottom right ) and read the amino acid protocol and thomas recipe....good luck !

Everyone needs to remember that the 1/2 life of sub is 36 hours.  so the dose you took a day and 1/2 ago, is only half gone, that compounded with what you took the day before that and the day before tht and so on.  that is why it is so important to taper as slow as possible.  if you decide to cut your dose, do it, but then stay there for 3 or 4 days, and then cut again and stay there for 3-4 days.  If you start getting any w/d symptoms, hot flashes, runny nose, stomach cramps, anxiety etc, you're going too fast and need to take an extra 1/2 pill that day, and the next day keep with the extra 1/2 for 3 days then cut by 1/2 pill each day for 3-4 days.  If you follow your doctor's advice, and dive into aftercare, you can do this.Assuming that the doctor has never had experience with abuse is not wise.  Just because they are doctor's this disease doesn't discriminate against them.  How many went to detox and the social workers, nurses, counselors were addicts in recovery???  I know alot of them were at mine.  Even if your doctor isn't a recovering addict, that doesn't mean they aren't very well educated on this disease.  Does a cardiac surgeon have to have had open heart surgery to treat his patients??  No.  Does a diabetes specialist have to have diabetes?  No, how about an OBGYN?  most of them are men????  they've never had a child?  Just because they aren't addicts, doesn't mean they don't know what they are doing.Vitamins and amino acids are good for everyone.  Not just those detoxing or in recovery.  Eat well, exercise, take your vitamins, and stay in contact w/counseling.  You are doing what you have to do RIGHT NOW to stay sober, and that's all you need to focus on right now.  As the rest of life falls into place,  THEN begin to think about tapering off.
